results.title: Looking at animals: animals with one foot
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: The appearance and characteristics of slugs and snails (gastropods) are shown. The muscular action of a common land snail in movement illustrates the meaning of the word “gastropod” (stomach-foot). Both terrestrial and aquatic snails and slugs are studied.

results.title: Looking at animals: amphibians
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: The characteristics of frogs, toads, newts and salamanders are described, compared and contrasted. To illustrate the great variety among amphibians, a European tree frog, a giant toad, an American bullfrog, a fire salamander, a muc-puppy and an axolotl are shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids

results.title: Look what's going around
results.brief_description: A film on venereal disease. Set largely in a public health clinic, information is presented informally by a physician and a public health investigator. Animation is used to present facts, while discussion by a group of young people presents attitudes to help dispel the sense of shame. Subjects emphasised are ease of treatment, symptoms, spread of the disease, the reasons for identifying contacts, and modes of prevention.

results.title: Look to the forest
results.brief_description: Fire and flood, wasted resources and barren lands are the penalties of forest destruction, warns this film, as it describes basic measures to preserve Canada’s prime source of national wealth. Scenes of the wilderness created by stripping land of protective trees show the need to halt careless exploitation. Contrasting the slow process of re-seeding with the swift, modern methods of felling trees, the film urges planned cutting to ensure a continuing protected yearly crop and waste salvage. (Award: Toronto)

results.title: Look to live: a guide to hazard perception
results.brief_description: Designed to assist learner drivers studying for their Probationary Licence Test to pass the new hazard perception component of the test. The video and workbook kit enables the instructor and student to discuss the issues raised.

results.title: Look it up: dictionary habits
results.creator_credit: David A. Smart and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Designed to motivate the dictionary habit especially for spellings, meanings, and pronunciation, this film shows students that the dictionary contains other useful information, such as synonyms, antonyms, derivations, prefixes, suffixes and information on geographical, historical and biographical matter.

results.title: Look before you eat (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A practical look at our eating habits, their relationship to our health, and the influences of advertising on our food choices. Examines experiments with the sugar, fat and salt intake of a group of students. Also looks at the role of the food industry and vending machines. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Look at Wales
results.brief_description: A selection of the tourist attractions in the towns, villages and countryside of Wales. Includes scenes of the Royal National Eisteddfod, and landscapes of mountain and valley contrasted with the bustling civic centre of Cardiff.

results.title: Look at me
results.brief_description: This video graphically illustrates in dramatic style the problem facing a teenager whose dog is run over and in urgent need of help. Nick is hearing impaired. An alert young man with limited speech, he is devastated when his dog, Smoky, his closest friend, is run over. In his efforts to get help he grabs Gavin, a passing cyclist, and desperately tries to make him understand his problem; but Gavin thinks Nick is a “right Wally”. “Look at Me” is a compelling introduction into the everyday problems facing the hearing impaired.

results.title: Look at life: under your feet
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description: An unusual angle on London indicating the wealth of history concealed under crowded streets. Looks at many of the underground services which play an important role in the life of the city; the great electricity tunnels under the Battersea Power Station and the Thames; the water mains and the labyrinth sewers; the Postal Service tube railways; the Chancery Lane silver vaults; and a 700 year old carmelite crypt. Narrated by Tim Turner.
